column2: image=[[File:Joona Kujanen - Nar at the gate of Moria.jpg
caption="Nar at the gate of Moria" by [[:Category:Images by Joona Kujanen
Dwarf]], the sole companion of King [[Thrór]] when he set out to wander in the wilds of [[Middle-earth]].

column1: Virtually nothing is known of Nár. However what is known is that he set out with the King of Durin’s folk from [[Dunland]], where the Thrór's following of relatives and subjects were living at the time to find his fortunes in wider world.
Their journey eventually brought them to the old [[Dwarves
column2: dwarf]]-halls of [[Moria]], now infested with [[Orcs]] and [[Trolls]]. Disregarding the pleas of Nár, Thrór insisted on entering [[Moria
column3: Khazad-dûm]] while Nár stayed behind and waited for the king not far from the gate.

column1: That was the last any Dwarf ever saw of Thrór alive. He was beheaded by the Orcs, and their chieftain [[Azog]] branded his own name on Thrór's brow. The Orcs allowed Nár to live so he could return to Thrór's son [[Thráin
column2: Thráin II]], with a message that Azog now ruled in Moria, and that Dwarves best stay away lest they suffer the same fate.

column1: Nár returned to Dunland where his message caused such anger amongst his people that it raised a call to arms among all seven Dwarf Houses to avenge the elder high-king of their race, leading the [[War of the Dwarves and Orcs]].
In the climactic [[Battle of Azanulbizar]], Azog himself was slain along with thousands of others on both sides.<ref>{{App

column2: Dvergatal]]''. His name means "Corpse".<ref>Chester Nathan Gould, "Dwarf-Names: A Study in Old Icelandic Religion", published in ''Publications of the Modern Language Association of America'', Vol 44 (1929), issue #4, pp. 939-967</ref>
